newsitem.title: USA: Mutilation-rapist pleads not guilty in Fla killing.
newsitem.headline: Mutilation-rapist pleads not guilty in Fla killing.

text.p: Lawrence Singleton, convicted in California of raping a teenage girl and chopping off her arms, pleaded not guilty Wednesday to a charge of stabbing to death a prostitute in Florida.

Singleton, who served eight years in prison for the California attack and moved back to his Florida birthplace after his release, was arraigned on a charge of first-degree murder in the Feb. 19 killing of Roxanne Hayes, 31.

Police called to Singleton's home near Tampa found him blood-spattered and standing by the nude body of Hayes, who police said had 99 prior arrests, most for prostitution. She had been stabbed repeatedly in the chest.
Singleton, 69, denied killing Hayes to the first deputy on the scene, then said to reporters as he was led away: "They framed me the first time but this time I did it."

Singleton, dressed in an orange jailhouse jump suit, slippers and a blue demin jacket, appeared subdued and looked down at his feet as assistant state attorney Lyann Goudie told Judge Bob Mitcham that Florida would seek the death penalty.
Singleton spoke only once, answering softly "no sir" when Mitcham asked him if he had ever used any other names.
Court records indicated Singleton had assets of $500 in cash and a $600-a-month pension.

Assistant public defender John Skye offered a plea of not guilty on behalf of his client and asked Mitcham to bar the state from attempting to subpoena psychiatric records from a local hospital that treated his client after a suicide attempt in early February, days before the killing.
"Is Mr. Singleton currently under a suicide watch?" Mitcham asked. When Goudie said no, Mitcham ordered her to "look into that matter."
A hearing was set for March 18 on the motion to suppress psychiatric records. No trial date was set. Skye asked for time to assemble records from California.

Singleton served eight years of a 14-year California sentence for raping and mutilating Mary Vincent in 1978. When he was released on parole, no community in California would accept him and he spent a month after his release living on the grounds of San Quentin prison before moving to Florida.
